comment.narrative: 1. Kazakhstan is the largest GHG emitter in Central Asia with annual emissions of 243 MtCO2e . 2. The transport sector is its fastest growing source of CO2 emissions projected to increase from 9 MtCO2/yr in 2008 up to 22 MtCO2/yr in 2012 and 36 MtCO2/yr in 2020 . 3. A significant share of transport emissions is associated with ground transportation in the former capital city of Almaty, the largest and most densely populated city in the country with a population of 1.6 million . Its population is expected to exceed the 2 million threshold in the next 3 to 5 years. 4. Using the annual growth factor of 18% for motor vehicles in Almaty from 2003 to 2008, a business-as-usual (BAU) approach to urban transport in Almaty will result in a steady increase in CO2 emissions of 16.8 million tonnes by 2015 and 24.0 million tonnes by 2020. 5. The main sources of GHG emissions from Almaty motor vehicles have been and will consist of the products of combustion from gasoline and diesel fuels. The viable alternative to private cars should be public transport. Unfortunately, Almaty’s public transport has evolved into a system that does not provide for comfort, convenience and efficient services to commuting passengers. Almaty has an extensive surface passenger transport system comprised of autobus, trolleybus and tram routes. The system, however, is poorly regulated delivering urban transport services that cannot compete with the private car for efficiency and comfort. With a lack of technical, managerial and fiscal capacity to deliver safe reliable public urban transport, there is a wide variance of service quality and a low public perception of the system.

description.narrative: The project will achieve this objective via four components: 1) policy development and implementation; 2) market development; 3) education and outreach; and 4) demonstration projects embodying best practices and technology.

title.narrative: Promotion of energy efficient lighting in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women

The project will achieve this objective via four components: 1) policy development and implementation; 2) market development; 3) education and outreach; and 4) demonstration projects embodying best practices and technology.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

1. Electricity consumption and associated GHG emissions from lighting 2. Share of incandescent lamps, CFLs, and other types of conventional and efficient lighting 3. Proportion of mercury recovered from spent lamps

comment.narrative: 1. 10.0 TWh/year and 9.3 million tonnes of CO2/year 2. Incandescent lighting accounts for 77 percent of all lighting in buildings 3. Not defined quantitatively; collection and recycling only from state agencies and larger enterprises, not general public

1. Preparation and agreement of the list of technical equipment for a testing laboratory together with Technical Committee. Purchase (or purchase of additional equipment) of technical equipment for a state laboratory. 2. Elaboration of regulations “Designing of lighting for public buildings” 3. Elaboration and realization of methodology for introduction of energy efficient lamps for general public 4. Implementation of phytodiode lighting demo-projects.

1. Jointly with the Institute of Metrology and the National Center of Accreditation there is prepared a list of the required equipment. Also together with the responsible authority there was elaborated the system of quality control of the lighting products, including use of laboratories. Purchase of technical equipment for lighting laboratories is planned for 2016. 2. There are prepared drafts of amendments for “Designing of lighting for public buildings” construction norms and regulations. The regulations are now in the process of agreement and approval at the Committee for construction issues (responsible authority). 3. In the 4th quarter of the year there was started the discount program for promotion of energy efficient lighting among public at large. The pilot activities cover several big cities and suburbs. 4. The 1st pilot project on phytodiode lighting is realized in a village basement. There were obtained results, i.e. vegetables for a shorter vegetation period, and which can be grown during any season. This pilot project is good to be spread among farmers and presents interest in winter period when traditional greenhouses don’t function.

1. Developing of a standard for measurements, verification, and evaluation criteria of energy services 2. Procurement (retrofitting) of technical equipment for a laboratory 3. Realization of a discount program with large scale awareness campaign 4. Lighting market research regarding use of lamps and lighting fixtures (set park) in basic segments of application 5. Testing of energy service contract for pilot projects on energy efficient lighting in budget sector. 6. Development of pilot project for target groups: socially vulnerable groups including people with low income.

1. There are worked out method and methodological recommendations for energy services in lighting sector (verification, and evaluation criteria). Method and recommendations are submitted for work to the supervising ministry. Normative documents determine “game rules” for business which in its turn enable its active and transparent participation in this trend 2. Technical equipment was additionally purchased for five testing laboratories for verification of imported lighting equipment in Kazakhstan. 3. There was carried out discount program for LED lamps through coupon service with a wide awareness campaign in four Kazakhstan regions which lasted for 4 months. 4. There was prepared market research and lighting market forecast in the Republic of Kazakhstan: (1) lighting market research in terms of use of lamps and lighting fixtures in main sectors; (2) calculation of energy consumption reduction in lighting realized at the expense of budget funds. 5. Together with the Ministry for Investments and Development there was tested an energy service contract on the building of the MID RK. The project assisted to carry out lighting audit and develop concept to prepare energy service contract. There was selected a company which shall implement lighting modernization on 39 floors using ESCO mechanism. 6. Concept for realization of a pilot project on energy efficient lighting among socially vulnerable groups has been developed. The concept is agreed with the Ministry of Health and Social Development. In order to start the pilot project there were prepared and sent out letters from the Ministry to regions regarding selection of a pilot region. Practically all the regions refused to participate in the pilot project saying that the retirees’ electricity expenses do not exceed the maximum admissible norm of consumption and many people are already using LED lamps.

1. Preparation of infrastructure for test laboratories of lighting equipment of Kazakhstan for accreditation. 2. Sociological research «Energy efficient lighting awareness and public opinion» 3. Preparation of Final report on terminal evaluation of the project. 4. Technical reequipment of the KazInMetr laboratory of the CTRM MID RK. 5. Installation of energy consumption counters at the administrative building (on-line monitoring)

1. The infrastructure to test lighting equipment in Kazakhstan has been provided for test laboratories. The laboratories staff was trained, the documents were prepared for the accreditation. 2. Sociological research on «Energy efficient lighting awareness and public opinion» has been performed. 3. Preparation of the Final report on terminal evaluation of the project has been prepared. 4. Technical reequipment of the KazInMetr laboratory of the CTRM MID RK has been realized. 5. Installation of energy consumption counters at the administrative building (on-line monitoring) has been carried out.

description.narrative: To phase out inefficient lighting and transform lighting markets towards greater energy efficiency while ensuring product quality and costeffectiveness as well as safe disposition of spent mercurycontaining lamps
Adoption of IL phaseout and associated policies

comment.narrative: IL phaseout adopted but without specific implementation plans
IL phaseout and full range of accompanying policies implemented including technical standards

By the Energy saving and energy efficiency Law dated January 13 2012 the incandescent lamps are subject for a gradual withdrawal
The Law includes a few phases of realization

description.narrative: NIP update, integration of POPs into national planning and promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan

title.narrative: NIP update, integration of POPs into national planning and promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan
NIP Update, Integration of POPs into National Planning and Promoting Sound Healthcare Waste Management in Kazakhstan
NIP Update, Integration of POPs into National Planning and Promoting Sound Healthcare Waste Management in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

To reduce the releases of uPOPs and other globally harmful pollutants into the environment by promoting sound HCWM in Kazakhstan, to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm Convention.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Outcome 1. Update of the National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention is prepared and coordination on chemical MEAs is enhanced. Outcome 2. Mercury inventory and Reduction plan prepared. Mercury waste generated by the health sector is managed soundly. Outcome 3. POPs emissions from healthcare waste incineration are reduced through a replacement of installations on HCW incineration by alternative in the selected regions.

comment.narrative: No inventory on new POPs. NIP not updated. Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced. Low level of practical knowledge and use of non-combustion techniques. Baseline emissions constitute 124.88 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.65 g TEQ/a to bottom ash. No training on new POPs is currently planned on POPs issue in Kazakhstan. Limited information on new POPs is available. Original 2003-2005 uPOPs inventory conducted with a limited set of industrial sources and outdated. No full range of POPs and POPs in goods/environment is handled by existing laboratories. No POPs coordination center. Ecological Code contains only general information on POPs management (chapter 40 on dangerous chemicals), with amendments related to PCBs. No national training held on new POPs. No previous larger scale efforts applied to build capacity of related stakeholders on mercury negotiations, mercury convention, mercury associated risks etc. No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product. No database on sources and mercury releases is in existence. No full understanding of scale impact on human health.

Component 1. To conduct inventory of new and unintentionally POPs. Improvement of legislation system related to issues of POPs, mercury and healthcare waste handling. Component 2. To reduce the volume of produced mercury waste in the selected hospitals. To conduct the assessment of of the situation on mercury releases, prepare recommendations for safe mercury management and Minamata Convention ratification. Component 3. To select the best affordable technologies and testing healthcare waste treatment installations in the selected region, i.e. by the alternative non-incineration methods.

Component 1: Workshops with the title ‘Outlining national priorities and action plan for the inventory of mercury, persistent organic pollutants, healthcare wastes reduction’ were delivered in pilot regions in order to enhance practical collaboration during inventory of POPs and mercury. With the view to promote the project and create a platform for discussions about efficient wastes management, the project contributed to organization and delivery of the Round Table ‘Strategic development of the wastes processing sector in Kazakhstan’ organized within the framework of the 11th Central Asian Specialized Exhibition EcoTech 2015. Inventory of new uPOPs is going on. The following activities were implemented to ensure a synergetic effect of three Conventions: a database with data on implementation of three conventions created; analysis on how provisions of three conventions are implemented in the Republic of Kazakhstan conducted; analysis of best international practices in implementing three conventions conducted; analysis of provisions of three conventions and resolutions of conferences of the parties conducted to set implementation priorities for Kazakhstan. For capacity building in the field of laboratory analysis, control and monitoring of POPs representatives of KazHydroMet and a representative of the laboratory of the Ministry of National economy that analyzes a content of dioxins in food took part in the International Symposium on Persistent Organic Pollutants organized by the International Organization “Dioxin 20XX”. A study tour to Recetox POPs Monitoring Center of the Stockholm Convention Secretariat (Czech Republic) was arranged for employees of governmental and private laboratories to raise their awareness about methods of POPs analysis.
Component 2: Country-wide mercury assessment and initial inventory of possible mercury sources conducted; recommendations on accession to Minamata Convention prepared for the RoK Government; the Concept was included int

1 component. Conduction of inventarization of POPs. NIP update plan for the 2017-2028yy. was approved by the Ministry of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan. More than 1000 personnel (representatives of governmental bodies, enterprises and NGOs) raised capacity building by means of conduction the seminars and trainings on the issues of POPs, mercury and medical waste management. With purpose of awareness raising on the issues of mercury management via online course. . 2 component. It was conducted the mercury inventarization in the Republic of Kazakhstan (first stage). Report “National inventarization of mercury emission in Kazakhstan” and Plan on mercury reduce was discussed with all interested sides and was submitted to the Ministry of Energy of RK. 3 component. Procurement of equipment (autoclaves) and specialized vehicle. Created six pilot Centers. 4 component. During the project realization 90 publications were submitted in the mass media information. In 2017 26 publications were submitted. The brochure and movie on project activity was prepared and submitted to the project national partners. It was conducted seminar training in the Central-Asian region for the representatives of Governmental bodies and UNDP of following countries: Azerbaijan, Kyrgyzstan, and Uzbekistan. Final Assessment and Final Conference was conducted in high level.

Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced
Low level of practical knowledge and use of noncombustion techniques
Baseline emissions constitute 12488 g TEQa to air and 065 g TEQa to bottom ash

Midterm
Releases reduced to 8608 g TEQa to air and 046 g TEQa to bottom ash
End of project
Releases reduced to 1638 g TEQa to air and 011 g TEQa to bottom ash

Three 3 pilot areas selected for demonstration of alternative noncombustion technologies in treatment of healthcare wastes as a replacement of existing basic incinerators with no installed stack air cleaning systems These are Kostanay Astana capital and UstKamenogorsk provinces
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed And in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in all 8 inpatient medical facilities
For a number of selected incinerators 1 in pilot Kostanay province and 2 in UstKamenogorsk province as Astana authorities declined on tests exemplar stack emission tests were conducted Dioxin and furan emissions exceeded the EU established maximum allowable concentrations MACs on average by 28 times
Based on technical advice from international expert the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas Kostanay Astana and UstKamenogorsk
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work and separate out plastic parts for disinfection
The use of needle cutters to allow for the segregated collection of sharps metal and separation of remaining plastic parts of the healthcare waste has been set in the legislation Decree of Ministry of Health no 127 dated 24 February 2015
Same decree provided for use of alternative methods for healthcare waste treatment
Four 4 workshops were held as described in the previous section to raise awareness of government agencies and medical facilities about alternative ways for healthcare waste treatment 300 people

The Concept of Transition of Kazakhstan to the Green Economy GE Djasyl Damu included general reference to air pollution by dioxins section 36 The Action Plan to implement the Concept of GE included a measure to ensure strengthening of the technical capacity of regional analytical laboratories to obtain reliable operational data on the pollution of surface and groundwater soil and air in order to undertake rehabilitation and preventive measures identification and study of pollution areas originating from landfills in order to identify areas in need of cleaning and rehabilitation

description.narrative: Studies on existing POPs analytical and monitoring capabilities for the whole range of POPs with focus on new POPs carried out

comment.narrative:
A few laboratories identified in the course of NIP preparation and GEFUNDP PCB management programme
Laboratories are currently only nationally accredited for PCB analyses
Draft POPs national monitoring plan developed by RECETOX a Stockholm Conventions Regional Centre in the Czech Republic

National POPs monitoring plan approved as part of relevant national policies and documents
Participation in regional monitoring networks

Existing laboratory capacity has been assessed
About nine 9 laboratories have the potential to determine uPOPs in the various environmental media provided methodologies are provided and accreditation is supported to enable full commercial activity
Two 2 laboratories were identifiedselected to receive project support for national accreditation
Maximum allowable emissions for dioxins and furans have been set by Decree of Ministry of Energy 26 of January 21 2015
Further amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu Green Economy National Development Programme
A capacity building program on POPs risks undertaking a POPs inventory and monitoring of POPs has been developed
This is based on bilateral assistance from UNDPCzech Trust Fund deployed before in the GEFUNDP PCB management programme in Kazakhstan The RECETOX Brno Czech Republic based laboratory of regional importance is a partner selected for this activity While training will be provided by RECETOX the project will support travel of 15 laboratory staff
The following laboratories will participate Central SanitaryEpidemiological KazHydroMeteorological Central Environmental and private laboratories
Participation in regional laboratory networks is possible after capacity building part is complete and national accreditation is in place

description.narrative: Policy institutional frameworks and enabling regulatory environment are in place to ensure better control on POPs accumulation and emissions

Capacity building programme trainings and consultations for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs related risks POPs monitoring institutional roles and responsibilities POPs control legislation benchmarks and enforcement

comment.narrative:
No national training held on new POPs developments in the Stockholm Convention and NIP update guidelines
Currently prevailing insufficient knowledge on new POPs their risks and control measures and approaches

At least two 2 complementary workshops held
Sixty 60 stakeholders participated in workshops
Results of stakeholder consultations
NIP update formulated

Four 4 regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs including new POPs in three pilot provinces of the country for territorial municipal health sanitary and environmental control administrations including hospitals as well as for central authorities and industrial associations 300 participants in total
Overall six 6 consultation meetings held at the indicated four 4 general workshops and two 2 at the premises of Ministry of Energy during September November 2014
NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30122014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention
Activity completed

description.narrative: Institutional coordination and compliance with international agreements improved through firmer institutionalization of POPs issues into national structures

comment.narrative:
No POPs coordination center in existence due to lengthy Governments approval procedures and unaligned MEP mandate and mismatch of proposed workplans to 2028 with 3 year long financial planning processes
POPs coordination happens in a fragmented manner with no alignment of roles
Nu funding sources to sustain POPs coordination function are available

POPs group meets regularly to guide the NIP update process
Institutionalization of new POPs issues into relevant line ministries ensured according to defined roles
Coordination mechanisms on POPs issues institutionalized and embedded into draft regulations sent for Governments review and approval
Funding sources to ensure the mechanisms sustainability are defined consulted on with MoF and proposed for inclusion in national planning

According to the Minutes of the Meeting with the Minister of Energy from 29 June 2015 19010101101 the establishment of a working group on POPs management issues is currently planned to become a dedicated group on national POPs management issues
Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decisionmaking board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant HTI high temperature incineration in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices
The development of proposals for the institutional structure of public authorities and organizations responsible for the implementation of the three conventions Basel Rotterdam and Stockholm are planned by the project team in consultations with relevant stakeholders
It is also planned to identify measures to assist the work of the state bodies on the implementation of the three Conventions

description.narrative: National Implementation Plan NIP on Stockholm Convention obligations with inclusion of new POPs reviewed and updated with elaboration of specific action plans on new POPs

comment.narrative: The Government is carrying out several noncoordinated actions on POPs update of inventories on pesticidal POPs in 5 regions PCB management inventory and partial disposal planning better control of uPOPs improving of existing regulations

Final draft of the NIP completed and circulated for review within the main stakeholders
Updated NIP submitted for approval to the Government approved and submitted to the Secretariat

During the reporting period the project team has been working on updating the NIP in regards of the introduction of new POPs A national contractor firm of 4 national experts was selected to organize the data collection and analysis process based on guidance form international consultant
Inventory on new POPs has been completed while work on unintentional POPs and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat
The updated National Implementation Plan on new POPs for 20152028 was approved by decree of Ministry of Energy 228 dated 30122014 It was submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention

description.narrative: National legal framework by aligning institutional roles reviewed and improved to include the issue of insofar unaddressed POPs uPOPs and new POPs

comment.narrative:
Ecological Code contains only general information on POPs management chapter 40 on dangerous chemicals with amendments related to PCBs supported by GEFUNDP programme on PCBs
The Government has plans to extend the provisions of chapter 40 to regulate emissions uPOPs
MEP plans measures to improve the operational control of industrial emissions including burning of fuels and promote the construction and modernization of facilities for cleaning exhaust gases in the steel industry

Final report on the improvement of current regulatory system for including the issues of insofar unaddressed POPs uPOPs and new POPs
Amended regulation drafted and submitted

National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy where environmental branch is now attached to no 26 dated 25 January 2015 has been created Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007
In addition maximum allowable concentration of dioxins in the air of populated areas has been defined in sanitary regulations 168 called Sanitaryepidemiological requirements to air quality in urban and rural areas soils and their safety content areas of urban and rural settlements conditions of work with sources of physical factors affecting people adopted by the Government on January 25 2012
The current new decree 26 Ministry of Energy sets emission standards for dioxinsfurans however no monitoring and control system over unintentional POPs exists in the country except for MACsemission limits
Further amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu Green Economy National Development Programme

description.narrative: Sectoral technical guidelines updated to include the issue of priority POPs including sampling and analysis methods

comment.narrative: Guidelines and action plans are being drafted on the sectors related to POPs waste and PCBs under the UNDP PCB project under Zhasyl Damu Green Growth initiative
Technical guidelines and action plans on POPs are submitted for approval by relevant state bodies
Planned in future reporting cycles

description.narrative: POPs inventories improved for informed decision making and priority setting
Capacity building programme trainings for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs risks inventories POPs tracking monitoring of data reported by responsible parties

comment.narrative:
Training on PCBs inventory and management is being carried out in the framework of the UNDP PCB project
No training on new POPs is currently planned on POPs issue in Kazakhstan
Limited information on new POPs is available

Web tool for on line training completed and published
At least three 3 complementary trainings completed
Training effectiveness assessed with both training feedback from the trainees and final tests
Number of requests for data sent out and processed
Number of visits made to related stakeholders

Training program on POPs risks and their sound management has been prepared with help of contracted consultancy firm Centre for facilitating Sustainable Development
This program will be placed on a weblink of consolidated training and awareness resources on sustainable development hosted under the National Development Programme Djasyl Damu Green Economy In addition it and other projects produced materials will be placed in the Ministry of Energys Information and Analytics Centre which is involved in career enhancement education activities for staff members
Other trainings included the central authority related training which engaged industrial enterprises on POPs inventorying which was held in September 2014 This was planned to easy access to date from industrial sector
During reporting period the project team together with territorial municipalities and health authorities had selected future project sites the sites where new alternative technology nonincineration will be installed for demonstration purposes These sites are located in Kostanay northwest Astana capital centrenorth and UstKamenogorsk east provinces
Three 3 trainings arranged in these three 3 regions at selected pilot sites for 250 people from territorial municipal health sanitary and environmental control authorities Additional main workshop held in September 2014 in Astana for central authorities and representatives of industry
Topics of these trainings included risks of POPs POPs monitoring institutional roles and responsibilities legislation for the control of POPs and measures for its implementation
Measuring training effectiveness is planned for future reporting cycles
Data on new POPs collected and assessed and formed an update request to the NIP with followup transmission of this information to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and later on to the Stockholm Convention Secretariat
This has been achieved by statistics and import database searches requests for information to industrial and private sectors company visits etc

description.narrative: National information system inventory on POPs expanded updated information on uPOPs and new POPs

comment.narrative:
Original 20032005 uPOPs inventory conducted with a limited set of industrial sources and outdated
Inventory of POPs pesticides stockpiles and burial sites limited to 20 of the country at the NIP stage
Under the sectoral programs Zhasyl Damu Green Growth for 20102014 adopted by the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan dated September 10 2010 924 a detailed inventory of all POPs and obsolete pesticides is envisaged but not started yet

uPOPs inventory completed using the most recent data available
POPs inventories updated for uPOPs and POPs pesticides covering all the territory of Kazakhstan
Industrial use of new POPs identified and possible chemical and nonchemical alternatives assessed
Inventory of stockpiles and burial sites of pesticides covering at least 70 of the country
Plan for maintaining and completing the above inventories elaborated and institutional responsibilities assigned
An information system on inventories of POPs substances established

Preparatory works performed for the determination of the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned
Based on open tender a national consultancy firm Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development was selected and subcontracted to support national level activities Overall four 4 national experts have been engaged in the process of NIP update This work was supported by an international expert to guide the process
Preparatory works have been undertaken to determine the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned
Inventory on new POPs has been completed while work on unintentional POPs and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat
NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30122014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention
Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decisionmaking board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant HTI high temperature incineration in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices
Information on POPs pesticides in particular will be useful to help Kazakhstan remove these wastes in future when the plant is in operation and this also provides a feedback mechanism on inventories to the Ministry of Energy
The main industries that use new POPs have been identified These sectors include agriculture engineering light industry and pharmaceutical industries
National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy where environmental branch is now attached to no 26 dated 25 January 2015 has been created

description.narrative: Sound healthcare waste management through uPOPs and mercury reduction approaches are demonstrated in 23 regions of the country
Development of Regional HCWM Management Plan in selected provinces

comment.narrative:
Baseline situation indicates no concerted action with adherence to BATBEP in medical sector
Sector is fragmented with disorganized players with no systemic approach to resolving uPOPs mercury issues and inappropriate HCWM practices
No specifically tailored action plan exists and quality data is missing
No previous capacity building and demonstration of BATBEP to reduce uPOPs and mercury releases implemented

The Management Plan is adopted and further actions and investments scheduled
Roadmap to support its implementation is approved by participating stakeholders

Based on technical advice from international expert the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas Kostanay Astana and UstKamenogorsk
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work and separate out plastic parts for disinfection
It is expected that these plans will be introduced into the strategic regional development plans later in 2015 to ensure they are put into practical implementation
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed And in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in 16 regions of the country and in all statefunded hospitals and medical facilities 154 medical facilities 2761 beds were assessed in the pilot regions
The project further plans for preparation of recommendations to improve the reporting system of waste generation levels demonstrate replacement of current basic incinerators for healthcare waste treatment with the alternative nonincineration technology and of mercury thermometers with mercuryfree alternatives electronic measurement devices
Data collection and analysis with regards to the treatment technologies for infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions has been concluded All incineration plants and plants processing infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions have been identified and mapped

description.narrative: Establishment of HCW treatment centres in selected sites

comment.narrative:
Overall waste management system is weak
Health facilities have no access to organised waste treatment system or the waste is incinerated in installations not fulfilling BEPBAT criteria
No nonincineration technologies procured and adopted to support new management system in selected regions
Waste disposal and transportation of waste in peripheral areas away from municipal or capital centers is disadvantaged due to high price
Low quality of service provision results in additional sanitary risks

HCW treatment centres successfully operate at preliminary planned capacity 950 tons per annum
Pricing policies implemented at target groups of stakeholders and service providers
Applicable recommendations on possible pricing criteria proposed for legislative amendments
Waste reduction amounts and uPOPs reductions are measured and reported on

Tenders to open in the second half of 2015 Activities planned in the next reporting cycles
Project plans the development of a proposal for setting tariffs on safe disposal of healthcare wastes

description.narrative: Pilot HCWM projects in selected hospitals including phaseout of mercury containing thermometers

comment.narrative:
No target hospitals for pilots defined before baseline assessment
Waste minimization and segregation at source not practiced
No alternative nonmercury thermometers and alternative product substitution demonstrated
No model facilities with individual action plans pilot sustainable BATBEP and reduction in waste generation and uPOPsmercury releases
BATBEP are not up taken on a larger scale
Overall waste management system is weak

BATBEP uPOPs and mercury reduction policies are implemented and targets recorded
Mercury thermometers are replaced by electronic devices with resulting mercury waste safely handled
Health facilities dispose IHCW in noncombustion installation
Evaluation and documentation of practical results inclusive of waste amounts minimized uPOPsmercury releases reduced in conjunction with Outcome 4

Three pilot areas have been identified UstKamenogorsk East Kazakhstan oblast Kostanai oblast and Astana city Eight 8 pilot hospitals have been selected Astana Research Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics Central Road Hospital EastKazakhstan oblast CSE on EAR Center of Mother and Child CSE on EAR UstKamenogorsk city hospital 1 CSE on EAR Central District Hospital of Katonkaragay District and Kostanay oblast CSE on EAR Kostanai Drug Dispensary SCCE Oblast Hospital SCCE Zhitigarinskaya CDH
A baseline assessment for each pilot hospital has been conducted using the individual Rapid Assessment IRAT tool developed under the Global Medical Waste project as well as the Guidelines for conducting a baseline assessment of an experienced medical institution A registry database of hospitals in pilot regions has been created and collection of data has been carried out in all hospitals of the pilot regions 154 facilities 2761 beds
During reporting period the project team assessed at the pilot sites their methods for healthcare waste treatment and determined based on guidance from assigned international expert with field visits processing capacities and design with or wo steam generator shredder required for each pilot hospitalhealthcare facility
ITB for procurement of nonincineration technologies six 100 kgh autoclaves two 20 kgh autoclaves for distant districts and 1 more potential 20 kgh autoclave if in case budget allows are planned for formulation for the second half of 2015 to supply technology in 2016
Healthcare waste management HCWM plans have been developed for the three 3 pilot regions and project is actively working on getting these HCWM plans approved and the inclusion of main indicatorspriorities into the strategic regional development documents for the target pilot areas
A tender for the procurement of mercuryfree thermometers will be soon announced It is planned to procure 15000 units of these electronic substitutes

description.narrative: Review of national policies and update of HCWM regulatory framework and road map

comment.narrative:
No comprehensive conceptual note on improving HCWM policies is in existence
No currently established emission standard for waste incineration POPs heavy metals
No legal provisions exist except minimum temperature standard for healthcare waste incineration
No technical standards set for hazardous healthcare waste treatment including noncombustion methods
No current requirements defined for waste management plans and country budget does not consider nonincineration technologies for wider replication
Public procurement rules do not include provisions on EPP procured products can still contain heavy metals and other harmful substances and the lowest price criterion is the main foundation
Reporting systems on waste amounts tracking and monitoring are underdeveloped

Legislative improvements through amendments in the EcoCode are submitted for final approval by the Government
Technical standard for hazardous healthcare waste treatment including noncombustion methods is established in close consultations and forms a part of legislative improvements
Public procurement rules are amended and EPP criteria are set
Awareness raising workshops and media reports at least 3 complementary workshops for medical and private sectors and 10 media reports
National reporting to POPs convention improved

An assessment of the current legislation on healthcare waste handling issues has been completed
Project further evaluated the system of state cooperation in terms of accounting and disposal of healthcare waste and assessed the environmental and sanitaryepidemiological requirements for healthcare waste handling
Gaps have been revealed in the type of statistical information is being prepared and collected by the National Statistical Committee on HCW area Various formats for data reporting are used in different provinces of the country some hospitals report in kgs tons or in unit measures
In this respect it is planned to develop proposals for changes in the national statistical system and industry reporting with one unified reporting mechanism and format to ensure consistency and aid decisionmaking process in future
Based on the regional healthcare waste management plans prepared for the three 3 pilot regions the project will prepare after pilot investment part with new technologies has been demonstrated a summary report for the healthsanitary authorities to request consideration to replicate these pilots on a wider scale in the country This will form a basis for the development of a unified national concept on healthcare waste management
Further after that step project plans to incorporate its recommendations into a national municipal waste management plan which will raise the status of medical wastes to that strategic level
The current decree 26 of January 2015 Ministry of Energy prepared on the basis of the projects intervention sets emission standards for dioxinsfurans Additionally amendments to the Environmental Code regarding emission standards for dioxinsfurans have been proposed by the project team
The previous governmental resolution of 2007 which set basic principles related to hazardous waste management after legal reform was transposed into a Ministry of Energy decree of November 28 2014 This decree listed disposal technologies on the basis of EU references which covered wastewater discharges releases from mining activities It is now planned to introduce changes to the list of BAT and incorporate information on technologies related to healthcare waste disposal
Proposals for amendments to the legislation on public procurement have been prepared and include environmental considerations to be added to standard cost considerations in the legislation This work is done jointly with a parallel GEFUNDP project on energyefficiency which deals in part with mercury waste coming out of CFL lamps These amendments are hoped for introduction into a main law on public procurement in 2016
Finally on legislation as of May 4 2015 project introduced amendments to previous governmental resolutions related to sanitary rules as applied to hospital operation These authorize the use of needle cutters and of alternative noncombustion waste disposal methods
Four 4 regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs including new POPs in three pilot provinces 300 participants in total
The project made an economic analysis of the existing healthcare waste disposal system as well as those of alternative disposal methods proposed by the project Certain maintenance issues were faced by owners of previously supplied nonincineration equipment microwave technology with embedded shredder due to frequent failures of the cutting blade replacement costs are high These problems were voiced during workshops
This material and the establishment of noncombustion centers for treatment of medical waste in three pilot areas will create a good foundation for future development of such system on a wider scale in the country

description.narrative: Improving sustainability of the Protected Area system in desert ecosystems through promotion of biodiversity-compatible livelihoods in and around Protected Areas

title.narrative: Improving sustainability of the protected areas system in desert ecosystems through promotion of biodiversity-compatible live-support sources in and around protected areas

description.narrative: The project objective is to enhance the sustainability of protected areas in globally important desert and semi-desert ecosystems
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Improved bio-geographic coverage of PA system: by 2020 an additional 5.3 million ha of the least represented desert and semi-desert ecosystems added to the PA estate. 2. Integrated land-use planning under implementation at 9 million ha of desert landscapes, ensuring preservation of ecosystem functions. 3. Demonstration of effective mechanisms and tools for engagement of local communities and other non-PA actors in PA management.

comment.narrative: 1. The current PA system falls short in terms of its bio-geographic representation, with desert ecosystems being currently under-represented. 2. PA design and expansion decisions are not considering the broader, landscape-level processes. 3. Collaborative management in PA governance in Kazakhstan remains a gap.

1. Improving sustainability and PA staff capacity building in desert and semi desert ecosystems 2. Landscape planning of Ile-Balkhash and Aral-Syrdariya project territories 3. Demonstration of sustainable practices on conservation and use of pastures, saxaul , riparian forests and wetlands on pilot territories 4. Development of project decisions on ecological monitoring system improvement and information distribution in target desert ecosystems 5.Community involvement in creation of PA Public Committees in pilot territories of SNNP Altyn Emel, Barsakelmes reserve 6. Implementation of “Eco-Damu” micro-finance program for target support of sustainable livelihoods of rural communities living around and in PA 7. Identification of ecosystem services in two project areas –Ile Balkhash and Aral-Syrdarya

1.Management plans of pilot PAs (Ustuyrt Reserve, Barsakelmes Reserve, Altyn Emel National Park) were developed and approved by the Order of authorized body. The biodiversity of desert and semi-desert ecosystems monitoring program on the example of pilot PAs was developed. 2. Landscape planning of Ile-Balkhash and Aral-Syrdariya project territories is determined on the basis of landscape approach. In the result, more than 13,0 mln. ha of lands are covered by territorial planning and basis for introduction of sustainable land-use management in targeted desert zones has been created 3.Four grant projects are realized in two project territories, two of them are on restoration of degraded lands (Aral-Syrdariya and Ile-Balkhash), 1 project – diversification of water-resistant monocultures areas , 1 project – restoration of poplar forests (Ile-Balkhash region) 4.The project decisions on structure and content of ecological monitoring data base web-portal are developed. 5. Informational company on mobilization of community was held. Public Committees in two project PAs (SNNP Altyn Emel, Barsakelmes reserve) are created. Community involvement in creation of PA Public Committees in pilot territories of SNNP Altyn Emel, Barsakelmes reserve 6. In the framework of “Eco-Damu” microlending program for targeted support of stable income source of rural population living around SNPA “Fund for financial support of agriculture” JSC had approved and funded 46 projects for the amount of 157,2 million KZT, including 17 business women’ projects. In Almaty region 20 projects worth 68.6 million KZT were financed, 21 project for the amount of 68.8 million KZT in Kyzylorda oblast, and 5 projects totaling 19.8 million KZT in Mangystau region. 7. To identify ecosystem services in two project areas in the framework of the works the classification of ecosystem services was completed, priority ecosystem services, and large-scale users of ecosystem services were identified, maps of ecosystem serv

1. Work on the expansion of the SPNA system in the desert and semi-desert ecosystems of Kazakhstan. 2. Enhancing the efficiency of management and strengthening the staff capacity of the pilot SPNA s. 3. Creating conditions for the habitation and migration of large hoofed mammals (kulan, gazelle) at the territory of the Altyn Emel National Park. 4. Development of a training program for middle age school children in the conservation of desert ecosystems. 5. Preparation of the Concept of sustainable land management for the Aral-Syrdarya and Ile-Balkashs project areas. 6. Demonstration of the 10 sustainable practices to reduce land degradation, management of riparian woodland and saxaul forests and wetlands, development of ecotourism in the 3 project areas. 7. Determination of the boundaries of the ecological corridor at the Ile-Balkashs project area. 8. Expansion of the Information biodiversity monitoring system and establishment of a system of information on the condition of desert and semi-desert ecosystems. 9. Establishment of the Public Council under the Ustyurtskiy Reserve and enhancing the capacity of the existing Public Councils. 10. Determination of the economic value of ecosystem services and introduction of pilot PES schemes in the project areas. 11. Economic evaluation and development of compensatory mechanisms for the loss of biodiversity in the Kansu area near the Ustyurtskiy Reserve. 12. Monitoring and evaluation of the sustainability of microcredit projects implemented under the Eco-Damu Microcredit Programme.

title.narrative: Establishment in Kazakhstan of the national ODA system

description.narrative: This project is aimed to support the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) of Kazakhstan in establishing of a national ODA system by providing expertize on development of conceptual, institutional and programmatic framework and mechanisms.
Expert support for the establishment of a national ODA system in Kazakhstan by developing conceptual, institutional and programmatic framework and mechanisms.
capital of a political entity

A dedicated operator /or institution under MFA established; number of capacitated specialists; a draft Law on ODA and related bylaws adopted and come into force The Programme document of cooperation with UNDP on 2015 is developed. No communication and/or visibility strategies exist; lack of knowledge among wide population and potential stakeholders
Communication and/or visibility strategies exist; knowledge among wide population and potential stakeholders distributed; web-site and visibility materials created.
a number of pilot projects developed and ready for implementation; database for ODA projects created; inventory of ODA projects done.

comment.narrative:
A dedicated unit on ODA at MFA was established. Neither ODA operator, no institution under MFA established, no capacitated specialists.
No communication and/or visibility strategies exist; lack of knowledge among wide population and potential stakeholders.
No ODA projects database; no projects on ODA; thematic initiatives of other line ministries exist: such as Green Bridge, DRR Center; Civil Service Hub.

On-demand capacity-building briefings on key issues in development cooperation and aid management.
Support to ODA related legislation and strategic documents.
Draft of a multi-year Country Assistance Program that defines geography of aids for future ODA agency developed.
Programming instruments developed: project cycle management; M&E system.
On-demand support to establishment of ODA system, including through written inputs and by facilitating the participation of Kazakh MFA in relevant global and regional events.
Develop a Communication Strategy, design web site for the agency

6 ODA capacity development trainings and 3 country-specific Briefings arranged and implemented for the National Partner in Astana with the support of: 1. UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub: 6 March and 3 July 2015 2. GIZ: 21 April 2015 3. CzDA: 22-24 April 2015 4. OECD DAC: 28-29 April 2015 5. USAID: 14-15 May 2015 6. Briefing on Kyrgyzstan (with the support of UNDP Kyrgyzstan): 29 June 2015 7. Briefing on Tajikistan (with the support of UNDP Tajikistan): 14 July 2015 8. Briefing on Afghanistan (with the support of UNDP Afghanistan): 02 November 2015
The following bylaw has been developed by the National Partner with the assistance of the project: 1. Order of the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Kazakhstan of 6 February 2015 № 11-1-2/43 “On the approval of the official development assistance project proposal form”: http://adilet.zan.kz/rus/docs/V15IY010430 • The following strategic and operational documents have been developed by the project and submitted to the National Partner: 1. Draft Kazakhstan ODA’s Mid-Term Strategy (Draft “Main Lines of the Policy of the Republic of Kazakhstan in the field of Official Development Assistance”) (to be formalized as a bylaw in the form of Decree of the President of Kazakhstan) 2. Key messages justifying the establishment of Kazakhstan’s ODA agency 3. Draft Monitoring and Evaluation Guidelines (to be formalized as a bylaw in the form of Order of the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Kazakhstan) 4. Draft Project Cycle Management (PCM) Guidelines 5. Draft ODA Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) reference document 6. Draft Kazakhstan’s ODA visibility guidelines 7. Various options of the Kazakhstan ODA agency’s logo 8. Draft Kazakhstan’s ODA Communication Strategy 9. Draft Concept of Kazakhstan ODA agency’s website 10. Draft designs of Kazakhstan ODA system’s leaflets

1. Regulatory legal acts (by- laws), concept documents of future national ODA agency developed and being implemented 2. Implementation of the Decree of Prime Minister of RK «On establishment of the Committee on ODA» particularly concerning the assistance to the MFA RK in the organization and holding the first session of the Committee, execution of protocol of the Committee session and etc. 1.9. Implementation of the Decree of the President of RK «On Main Lines of the Policy of the Republic of Kazakhstan in the sphere of ODA» 1.10. Implementation of the Order of MFA RK “On Approval of the Rules of Interaction with key line ministries and organizations in the sphere of ODA”, develop a Plan of events in the sphere of ODA and Plan of payment of voluntary contributions to the international organizations for ODA and submit into consideration by MFA RK

title.narrative: introduction of mechanisms of economic assessment

description.narrative: This project will aid in the valuation of natural resources and ecosystem services as well as institutionalize new capacities by improving standards of environmental management.

title.narrative: Mainstreaming Rio Conventions in Sustainable Development
introduction of mechanisms of economic assessment
introduction of mechanisms of economic assessment
introduction of mechanisms of economic assessment

description.narrative: This project will aid in the valuation of natural resources and ecosystem services as well as institutionalize new capacities by improving standards of environmental management.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1) Decisions to protect the global environment are better enabled 2) Technical and management staff sufficiently trained in the use and application of natural resource valuation tools, and decision-makers fully aware of natural resource valuation tools

comment.narrative: 1) Requirements of the Rio Conventions are not adequately incorporated in development planning Planners and decision-makers do not incorporate full value of ecosystem goods and services Evidence of public sector staff’s technical capacities related to the Rio Conventions is limited Despite expressed government commitment to the global environment, several issues undermine policies and efforts 2) There is a lack of capacity among agency staff and less than optimal understanding of natural resource valuation NRV guidelines and tools are not widely known among planners and decision-makers

1) Expert working groups (EWG) on three Rio conventions is established 2) Research on identification of world best practice in natural resource valuation, which can be applied in Kazakhstan is conducted and the report approved by the EWG 3) Six awareness-raising workshops are conducted at the national level for various target groups 4) TOT program developed 5) TOT based on developed program is held 6) Trainings on methods, instruments of biological resources assessment are developed fro wide audience of interested parties 7)Ecosystem services of project areas are valuated 8)Review of the international experience in payments for ecosystem services was presented to the stakeholders. 9) The recommendations on improvement of the legislation are developed. 10) Pilot schemes of payments for ecosystem services are developed under current and improved legislation 11) The main criteria of selection of large-scale development projects to make assessment of biological resources are developed

1. The expert working group is established and consists of international expert and two national experts on methods and practice of economic assessment of natural resources and biodiversity. 2. Research on identification of natural resource and biodiversity valuation and analysis of application in Kazakhstan is conducted. The review of international experience of economic assessment of natural resources and biodiversity. 3. Six awareness-raising workshops were conducted at the national level for various target groups in Almaty, Astana, Aralsk (Kyzylorda oblast), Bakanas (Almaty oblast). 4. TOT program consisting of 11 cases, practical sessions and presentations was developed 5. TOT based on developed program was held in Almaty. 13 specialist took part in the TOT. 6. Trainings on methods, instruments of biological resources assessment were developed for wide audience of interested parties. 7. The terms of reference was developed, the process of recruitment of expert is going on. Review of the international experience in payments for ecosystem services was conducted and was submitted to the stakeholders 9. The recommendations on improvement of the legislation were developed 10. Nine schemes of payments for ecosystem services were developed for integration it in current legislation. 11. The main criteria of selection of large-scale development projects to make assessment of biological resources were developed in frames of expert working groups.

1. Proposals on the improvement of the biological resource valuation system were submitted to the Parliament of Kazakhstan. Terms of references have been developed and experts are being sought to develop techniques for evaluation of the damage compensation as a result of illegal logging, fires and withdrawal of land. 2. Key indicators and techniques of economic valuation of wildlife resources and hunting concessions were identified by the example of the Ile-Balkhash pilot area 3.The analysis of the legislation of Kazakhstan in the field of the environmental impact assessment (EIA) was prepared for compliance with the international requirements/obligations. Recommendations were prepared based on the international experience to integrate techniques of economic valuation of ecosystem services into the process of the environmental impact assessment (EIA) and technical background reports (TEO) of the development projects. 4. The training module was developed to monitor the biodiversity funding. 5.Workshops, round tables were held as part of pilot researches on economic valuation of ecosystem services to develop capacities of stakeholders. Over 50 people from government agencies and private sector took part. Issues of the relevance of economic valuation of ecosystem services were addressed during the workshops to develop agriculture, fishery, forestry, hunting management and tourism sectors. 6.Calculations of economic valuation of ecosystem services were prepared for the proposed Ile-Bakash reserve and the first analytical report was prepared. 7. Calculations were made on economic valuation of ecosystem services in the Ile-Balkhash pilot area. This will allow to justify the need to create the reserve and identify clear PES schemes for conservation and sustainable use of ecosystems and biodiversity in Ile-Balkhash region. 8.The project initiative on introduction of offset mechanisms for the loss of biodiversity and ecosystems and valuation of ecosystem services and bio

1. Recommendations for improving the use of cadastral value-based techniques – cadaster of PAs, forest cadaster, fauna cadaster, including fish cadaster are prepared 2. The assessment method of compensation of damages as a result of illegal logging, fires and withdrawal of land is developed 3. Recommendations for mainstreaming and institutionalizing recommendations and related Rio Convention obligations into national policy of ecological decision-making are developed 4. At least 2 workshops are held, at least 50 civil servants are trained 5. Training module on economic valuation of ecosystem services of the Ile-Balkash pilot area is integrated into the study programme of at least 1 university 6. Economic valuation of changes in ecosystem services in Kansu is finished 7. The impact of gas industry on the populations of rare and key species of Ustyurt Plateau is assessed 8. Research related to economic valuation of ecosystem services of the Ile-Balkash pilot area is finished

1.In order to add the value to biological resources, methodological frameworks for cadastral valuation of forest resources, fish resources, wildlife resources were thoroughly analysed and a series of proposals for their improvement were presented to the Ministry of Agriculture’s Forestry and Wildlife Committee. 2.The methodology to assess damage compensations resulting from fires and illegal logging was reconsidered, and proposals for its improvement were presented to the Ministry of Agriculture’s Forestry and Wildlife Committee. The competent authority’s Scientific and Technical Council approved amendments to the assessment of compensations for damages to forest resources resulting from fires and illegal logging and rules for forming base rates of fees for the use of forests. 3.Recommendations for integrating value of biological resources and related obligations under the Rio Conventions into the country policy were prepared based on a pilot study of economic valuation of ecosystem services of the Ile-Balkhash Rezervat. 4.More than 100 representatives from research organizations, government agencies and private sector acquired new knowledge and improved their capacities through workshops and a training session on economic valuation of ecosystem services 5.A training module on eight (8) methodologies of economic valuation of ecosystem services with interactive applications was adopted by two educational institutions for introduction into the curricula of students of master programmes in economics and natural resources management starting from 2018. 6.Economic calculations of compensations for loss of biodiversity and grassland ecosystems within Kansu site were made. The findings were presented to government 7.The assessment of the impact of exploration works on soil, flora and fauna of the Ustyurt plateau was prepared. The research findings were used to prepare amendments to the rules for performing the environmental impact assessment (EIA), which were submit

comment.narrative: The income distribution of the Kyzylorda Oblast’s population (Gini Coefficient)

• Grant program for SMEs implemented. • To learn from the experiences of the East Kazakhstan region for the development of local self-government and the use of energy-efficient and water-saving technologies to solve local problems, representatives of 7 districts of the region took part in study tour to East Kazakhstan region • Grant program on self governance was implemented in two rural district of Kyzylorda region • TOT for social workers was conducted • Workshop "The environmental aspects of agriculture and sustainable management of ecosystems in arid regions of Kazakhstan" was conducted • Assessment of the current state of the agricultural practices in the territory of Kyzylorda region was conducted • Criteria for the selection of pilot sites developed • In order to disseminate knowledge on sustainable agriculture publication on best agricultural practices was issued

• 24 social workers and a staff member of the CHS were trained in sign language skills for special social services. • 50 social workers and employees of district employment coordination departments and social programs received training in improving the quality of social services. • More than 20 women and their family members who were subjected to domestic violence were advised and assisted in the "Crisis Center Jean" of the Open Society "Union of Women Entrepreneurs" in Kyzylorda. The Crisis Center is the only one in the region that carries out such activities to support women. • 30 young people from rural areas went through various trainings on raising the legal literacy and socio-psychological adaptation in the Club for Young People with Disabilities, open NGO "Brightness Kazakhstan". • 9 students of the college of tourism were trained in the school of green technologies in the village of Arnasai, which promoted their activity and development of the volunteer movement

• 9 women-craftsmen have increased their skills in design courses held in the house-fashion "Asyl-Design". • A seminar was held on the topic "Modern conditions for effective job search" organized by representatives of the successful, dynamically developing company HeadHunter (hh.kz), which was attended by representatives of government agencies, NGOs, employees of urban and regional employment centers, youth resource and online- centers. As a result, employment centers began using the HH database to find jobs for their beneficiaries. • NGO "Parasat" in Kazalinsky district opened a training and production sewing workshop, in which 5 rural women were employed, one of them with a disability. • Project "Intellect Center Shanyrak" at the regional library named after A.Tazhibaev: 45 people were trained at various courses of computer literacy, use of Internet resources in job search and, as a result, 5 of them were employed. • A "Volunteer Club" was established in PF "Arylu" in the regional rehabilitation center for disabled people from 20 volunteers, as well as more than 60 persons with severe disabilities were actively involved in various courses in art therapy, computer literacy and self-esteem.

description.narrative: - National and sectoral strategies/plans/guidelines are reviewed to include climate change adaptation in agricultural sector; number of strategies - State and private sector financing is assigned to agricultural development, with a specific emphasis on climate change resilience; amount of funding - Capacity for local, regional and national stakeholders on climate resilience and agricultural development increased; level of information-exchange and collaboration - Regional dialogue on food security supported; number of joint initiatives and partners

comment.narrative: Lack of both short-term weather and long-term climate information in Kazakhstan is viewed as a significant weakness in the agriculture sector. At the same time long-term and reliable prediction of weather forecasts for the growing season can increase the productivity of wheat production by up to 50% and improve sustainability and economic performance in Kazakhstan. Available climate information is sufficient to ensure adaptation to expected impacts. Therefore, a broader analysis of ongoing and needed interventions, with specific focus on the wheat sector and agro ecosystems, is needed. There is no common vision and understanding of the possible implications of climate variability and change on wheat and food security in the Central Asian region. In order to identify actions that can be taken individually and collectively to respond, a review of ongoing and completed actions is needed. These will be followed up by specific research on the wheat sector, with concrete recommendations and conclusions.

Developed concept of geoportal and established synoptic long term forecaster at the bases of Space research institute and Kazhydromet respectively.
More than 750 farmers are directly testing/approbating new package of long term climate forecast including drought forecasts.
More than 1240 farmers are benefited from participation in the climate variability and change trainings and workshop including field days.
Improved at least 80 stakeholders’ knowledge and experience at local level on climate resilient practices improved.
Six national institutions (Kazhydromet, Space Research Institute, KazAgroMarketing, KazAgroInnovation, Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Energy (Dept. on climate change adaptation)) with improved capacity to address climate variability and change.
More than 20 adaptation options demonstrated through established demonstration and pilot plots in the area of 22 ha and 44 multipurpose trials.
Produced 5 studies/expert reports/recommendations on wheat sector and climate change conducted and disseminated.
At least 80 Central Asian farmers, agricultural experts, land users and institutions with improved capacity to address climate variability and change
More than 20 learning and knowledge management products documented and disseminated through national and regional events arranged by the project.

1: Established comprehensive geoportal. 2. Developed Master plan on improving wheat production sector in Kazakhstan 3. Number of farmers using new best technologies and/or innovative climate resilient technologies through piloting and testing increased; 4. Developed Atlas of Wheat seeds in Kazakhstan 5. Established Central Asian Extension center at the basis of Tajik Agrarian Univeristy 6. International best practices and lessons learnt are disseminated to Central Asian countries and Afghanistan.

comment.narrative: 1.Lack of access to evidence-based knowledge on civil service development 2.Demand for building the capacity of national and local governments to implement development initiatives in an inclusive and participatory manner 3.Fragmented manner of Civil Service cooperation among the Hub participating countries
The Hub contributed to the development of effective systems of civil service in the participating countries in delivering public services effectively and efficiently

The Hub became a platform for systematic exchange of knowledge and information, through the study and dissemination of best practices. It facilitated the strengthening of the network of scholars and practitioners in the participating countries.
At the substantive level, the Hub employed knowledge management and partnership approaches that are well suited and appropriately customized to ultimately contribute to the establishment of modern, effective and sustainable civil service systems that meet societal expectations for a responsive and transparent civil service delivering public goods and services efficiently in the Hub’s participating countries. Through the Hub, participating countries engaged in exchanging and testing contemporary knowledge in order to build their capacity, in generating innovative solutions and practices, and thus contributing to civil service modernization and quality and excellence in public service delivery.
At the institutional level, the Hub adopted strategic planning practices and appropriate management processes to continuously monitor and evaluate the results of the work it carried out on knowledge management, South-South (East-East) partnership and cooperation activities and other triangular approaches, which are well suited and sufficiently customized to maximize its effectiveness.
One area of the Hub’s development activities is research and knowledge management. The Hub aspires to serve as a knowledge network or broker, and map, draw upon and, where gaps exist, carry out applied research and analysis on civil service development and professionalization.
Research is carried out through implementation of joint activities among the Hub’s participating countries. This modality allows the Hub and participating countries to both learn and contribute to the exchange of knowledge and experience in building efficient, effective, professional merit-based civil services; and innovative models for public service delivery.
Findings and c

The Hub participating countries have access to the global and regional trends in civils service reforms, as wel as to the innovations and best practices in public service delivery in the region. Civil service institutions of Hub participating countries are empowered via practical leverage on acquired knowledge, training and research skills and expert network drawn from the Hub activities, and benefited from peer-to-peer learning and South-South / East-East (SS/EEC) and Triangular Cooperation (TC) exchanges to apply and adapt innovations in civil service excellence.

One area of the Hub’s development activities is research and knowledge management. The Hub serves as a knowledge network or broker, and map, draw upon and, where gaps exist, carry out applied joint research and analysis on civil service development and professionalization.
Research is carried out through implementation of joint activities among the Hub’s participating countries. This modality allows the Hub and participating countries to both learn and contribute to the exchange of knowledge and experience in building efficient, effective, professional merit-based civil services; and innovative models for public service delivery.
Findings and conclusions of such efforts are published and disseminated through a series of knowledge products including case studies, regular and occasional thematic policy papers, and a biannual journal. These knowledge products provide guidance for civil service reform and public service delivery modernization efforts undertaken in the participating countries. Below is a list of some results delivered through research activities.
1. The Research Team developed 9 civil service country profiles of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine, Belarus and Tajikistan, examining these countries’ past, current, and future civil service reform policies, initiatives, development strategies and programmes. The country profiles were also updated as a supplement to the Global and Regional trends review study, and published as a separate knowledge product. 2. Considerable progress was achieved in terms of further development of the Journal of the Hub. First, concrete recommendations for the Journal’s strategic development have been made as a result of the first meeting of the new Editorial Board of the Hub’s Journal in April 2016. Second, online management of the Journal’s publication process was developed based on open Journals Software purchased and introduced by the team. Furthermore, all the previous issues of th

Increasing awareness of the participating countries about global and regional trends in civil service reforms, as well as the innovations and best practices in public service delivery in the region.Civil service institutions of Hub participating countries are empowered via practical leverage on acquired knowledge, training and research skills and expert network drawn from the Hub activities, and benefited from peer-to-peer learning and South-South / East-East (SS/EEC) and Triangular Cooperation (TC) exchanges to apply and adapt innovations in civil service excellence.

1. The Hub expanded its geography to South America and South Asia with Bangladesh and Brazil becoming the participants of the Hub, as such the number of the Hub’s participants increased to 38 countries. 2. The first comprehensive reports were developed within the expert support to Agency for Civil Service Affairs and Anti-Corruption by two large consultancy groups engaged by the Hub for (1) Development and introduction of a Common Framework of Competencies (Competencies Model), testing programmes for assessing competencies and determining the level of commitment to the values of the civil service for the Corps B administrative civil service positions of the Republic of Kazakhstan and (2) Development, introduction and implementation of a factor and point scale (grading and salary) system to support the reforms in Kazakhstan.
3. The Review of Global and Regional Trends in Civil Service – a joint publication of the Hub and the UNDP Global Centre for Public Service Excellence in Singapore, having been produced in the original English language in December 2016, was completed in Russian language and Kazakh languages, as such making it available for a wider audience in Kazakhstan and countries of the region. 4. The Hub’s second Annual conference “Partnership for civil service excellence” was held in Astana, bringing together the representatives from around 40 countries, including ambassadors and well-known experts in the field of civil service. The results of Hub's research generated much interest among conference participants, in particular, review of "Global and regional trends of civil service development". Participants noted the practical benefits of analytical materials – case-studies on public services delivery, anti-corruption intitiatives, civil servants’ motivation and country profiles of the civil service of the participating countries of the Hub, as well as the high level of Hub’s journal publications.
