Contribute to the long-term environmental sustainability and inclusive economic development of Kazakhstan through supporting the country's transition to a Green Economy model.

comment.narrative: In the follow-up to the Rio+20 process on sustainable development, Kazakhstan took a landmark decision to transition towards a sustainable Green Economy Concept, aimed at implementing a completely new development paradigm with particular focus on the water sector.

Inception report development and endorsement, view of economic instruments and MPWI bussnes models, demonstration projects in key sectors , form a pool of pilot projects. Multi stakeholder dialogue on pilot projects, pilot projects concepts developing

During 2015 Inception workshop was conductead and inceptionreport was developed adn approved by donor, NGOs Grant programme was launched, grants Agreements are signed, 3 pilot concepts were developed and approved by key stakeholders, workshop was organized for the reccomendations collection form key stakeholders and detailed work plans on pilot projects implementation developed,review of economic instruments and MPWI bussnes models started

Interim report of grant programme implementation, contracts for 4 pilot projects are signed, starting of pilot projects implementation, to prepare report on economic instruments in two sectors of Kazakhstan, to prepare a plan for Balkhash Alakol bassin saving, workshop and report on green indicators, review on dams in Kazakhstan

Under the pilot activities, on the territory of greenhouse facility, Training Center for Green Technologies has been established to train farmers, students, master's degree students, entrepreneurs and others. The trainees will be provided with practical skills required for agrarian sector, and will also study elements of the most promising energy and resource saving technologies that will help improve methods and ways of growing vegetables in a protected soil, and effectively use heat and energy, natural resources, and ways of provision of fresh vegetables to population round the year. Due to the grant program, 14 NGOs were supported to implement projects related to green economy. Overall, water consumption for irrigation at the pilot sites have been reduced 40%. Energy efficiency rose up to 20%, due to technologies harvesting of farmers increased up to 20%, water supply improved for 700 residents; 8 schools have access to clean water and 6 social buildings have access to hot water. 7 green business models have been developed and supported within the project through contest among youth, such as Water in AUL and Startup Bolashak. Green economy elements were integrated into the Balkhash-Alakol Basin Saving and Management Plan. This will enable to improve water quality and water disposal management of the Basin.

The target for the joint EU/UNDP/UNECE project is to demonstrate social, environmental and economic viability of the green technologies for water sector. The target will be achieved thought implementation of pilot projects in Astana city, Almaty, Aktobe and Kyzyl Orda regions. Moreover, project is setting up the targets such as: increasing visibility and awareness of the green technologies and build the capacity of the stakeholders in this area. These targets will be implemented in partnership with leading universities and civil society organizations of Kazakhstan.

The intended synergies between the key pillars of the project, i.e. improved governance of natural resources, increased efficiency in water management, the introduction of innovative technologies and economic considerations are increasingly becoming apparent. Legal approaches, economic considerations, innovative technologies, and novel business models come together in the series of pilot projects, which have been designed and partly constructed during this reporting period. Namely, Aktobe pilot project was totally completed and deliverables transferred to the Oblast Akimat. Kyzyl-Orda, Astana and Almaty projects are in an active implementation stage. The grant program focusing on civils society has been completed in August 2017 and provides examples of the synergies to be expected in the implementation of the three major pilot projects currently being realized. The target was implemented in strong partnership with leading universities, IFIs, state bodies and civil society organizations of Kazakhstan.

AIDS Center's capacity is being enhanced step by step. All required health products are under process of procurement. PR is now applying to local bodies to obtain permission for import of the procured goods. Related services, such as text developments, brochures design and printing, logistics and warehouse services are successfully procured: text was developed on the basis of IC; design and printing of brochures is now implemented by one of LTA-based companies; logistics and warehouse services will be provided by logistics company chosen on the basis of ITB for TB Project in 2014.

1) Distribute produced educational materials among end-users; 2) Provide PR with all needed documents to get pre-clearance for international procurement (condoms, syringes/needles, alcohol pads/containers, CD-4 cytometer, PCR equipment, Elisa sets) 3) Organize in-country logistics for imported goods (listed above) 4) Procure the goods ordered by PR additionally

1) Educational materials are produced and distributed among end-users; 2) PR is provided with all the documents required to obtain permission for import. Partially the goods were already delivered to KZ. Part of the goods is expected by the end of 2016. Distribution will start in 2017. 3) In-country logistics was properly organized. 4) Additional goods are in the process of procurement.

1) According to AWP 2017 to procure and deliver to HIV end-users the following goods: - PCR equipment (6 sets) - Condoms and lubricants for MSM - Naloxone - Printing of brochures for MSM, translation into KAZ 2) To procure logistics services for distribution of procured goods 3) Receive and distribute Autoblot-3000 and HIV Express-tests ordered in 2016

Procurement of Naloxone, upon donor (GF) approval, was returned under responsibility of HIV PR (RCAIDS). UNDP supported HIV PR in Naloxone in-country distribution only.
Additionally, upon request from HIV end-users, the following goods were procured and delivered to 13 HIV facilities, where ELISA equipment was installed: - Air conditioner - UPS - network filter - mouse for laptop - Russian alphabet stickers for laptop keyboard
Logistics company was successfully hired (by means of local RFQ) to manage procured health and non-health products distribution among HIV end-users in KZ

description.narrative: Civil service reform advocacy through ethics, meritocracy and corruption prevention measures
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption

Legislation on corruption prevention in civil service have been improved. Training programs and manuals on professional ethics, meritocracy and analysis of corruption risks are developed. By 2018 the number of precedents of corruption in civil service gets reduced.

comment.narrative: Management staff of civil service and civil servants do not systematically receive specialized training on ethics, meritocracy and prevention of corruption. Lack of regulatory documents on professional ethics, meritocracy and prevention of corruption.

Improvement of legislation on professional ethics, meritocracy and prevention of corruption in civil service, including through experience exchange. Strengthening the institutional capacity for training of civil service management and civil servants on professional ethics, meritocracy and corruption prevention.

International practice of ethics standards in public service has been analyzed to enlarge civil servants knowledge on ethics institutions and standards. Recommendations have been developed towards the changes in civil service and anticorruption legislation including draft law on access to information and code of ethics. Handbooks developed on Conflict of Interests and on Gifts to strengthen civil servants to strengthen the knowledge on ethics standards and regulations. Training videolectures on legal, social and economic implications of corruption in civil service has been recorded to strengthen the Civil Service Agency's training potential. The conferences on anticorruption issues have been supported to increase awareness raising among civil society and create effective communication with international community

Improvement of legislation on professional ethics, meritocracy and prevention of corruption in civil service. Strengthening the institutional capacity for training of civil service management and civil servants on professional ethics, meritocracy and corruption prevention.

Comparative analysis of international experience and national legislation was followed with recommendations to introduce corruption monitoring mechanisms and a law on meritocracy in civilian service. Two nationwide surveys on assessment of satisfaction of people with public services and level of corruption perception in the society provided analysis of implementation of corruption prevention strategy. 7 regional workshops for civil servants and public council members enhanced their potential to apply the laws on information, Public Councils and Corruption Prevention and increased the involvement of civil society in decision making process

Improvement of legislation on professional ethics, meritocracy and prevention of corruption in civil service. Strengthening the institutional capacity for training of civil service management and civil servants on professional ethics, meritocracy and corruption prevention.

Recommendations have been provided to minimize corruption risks in the ministries and agencies based on external analysis of 5 government agencies; methodological recommendations have been provided to assess performance of law enforcement bodies; proposals have been developed in drafting 2017-2020 Plan for implementation of Anticorruption Strategy; training for regional departments of the Civil Service Agency enhanced their potential in information campaign techniques that accompany implementation of Anticorruption Strategy

description.narrative: Analysis and application of the best practices to support the Republic of Kazakhstan in transition to “green economy”
Analysis and application of the best practices to support the Republic of Kazakhstan in transition to “green economy”
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: Result 1. Support in development of institutional and legislative framework for the promotion of economically sound solar energy development in Kazakhstan. Baseline: Target indicators on reducing of GDP energy intensity and the share of alternative energy sources in electricity generation defined. The legislation on introducing RES adopted and feed-in-tariffs for electricity produced from renewable energy sources identified for 15 years. Result 2. Development of Fisheries and Aquaculture. Baseline: The legislation on development of agriculture, the Program on development of agro-industrial complex for 2013-2020 ("Agribusiness 2020") and MA Strategic Plan identified main targets for development of commercial fish farming system, using state subsidies and determined the creation of conditions for natural and artificial fish resources reproduction as one of the activities in fishery industry. Result 3. Development and institutionalization of the "Green Bridge" Partnership Programme Baseline: “The Green Bridge Partnership Programme (GBPP) for 2011-2020, developed on the AGBI basis, was approved in 2012 by all states at the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development (Rio+20) as a cross-regional voluntary initiative on sustainable development, which is open for participation by all partners. There is no institutional and legislation base for implementing GBPP on national and regional levels

Component 1. Support of development of institutional and legal framework for economically feasible promotion of development of solar energy in Kazakhstan Within the framework of legal, regulatory and institutional system improvement for introduction of solar energy on national level Terms of References for preparation of recommendations for improvement of legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks for development of solar energy with a review of existing legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks in the area of solar energy with identification of barriers to development of solar energy have been developed. “Green Bridge” Partnership Program and Solar Energy Promotion Expert has been selected and hired on a competitive basis. Component 2. Fishery and aquaculture development Terms of Reference for legal expert of legal, regulatory and institutional framework, review of existing regulatory and legal framework, as well as institutional framework and barriers to development of sustainable fishery has been developed. Report on barriers to introduction of sustainable fishery and aquaculture development has been presented. Component 3. Further development and institutionalization of “Green Bridge” Partnership Program (GBPP). Investment memorandum of “Creation of “Green Bridge” Joint-Stock Company” investment project has been prepared In order to raise public awareness of GBPP following data have been prepared: Reports on extended consultations and negotiations conducted, Film about “Green Bridge” Partnership Program Primary analysis of international practices and making recommendations for implementation of “green economy” projects under GBPP.

1. Preparation of a draft concept for the enhancement of the legislation supporting renewable energy and making appropriate recommendations 2. Development of the structure of the solar resources Atlas and launching the process to develop one 3. Preparation of recommendations to improve the regulatory framework for sustainable fisheries and aquaculture 4. Preparation of training modules and training workshops to enhance the capacity of fishery workers 5. Preparation of a registry of green technologies in the key thematic areas of GBPP

1. Laws of foreign countries on renewables was reviewed; Kazakhstani laws and opportunities were analyzed to improve them for development of renewables; main factors influencing the development of renewable sources of energy were identified; market factors and competitiveness of renewables with the traditional energy were analyzed; draft Concept for improvement of regulatory and legal framework in the area of renewable sources of energy was prepared. 2.The baseline data were selected for the Solar Atlas. The existing interactive Solar Atlases were reviewed. The Concept for creation of the interactive Solar Atlas of the Republic of Kazakhstan was prepared. 3. Analysis of the current state of the regulatory framework for fisheries and concept bill “On making amendments and supplements to some legal acts on flora and fauna of the Republic of Kazakhstan”; analysis of internationally recognized guidelines (including the "Code of conduct for responsible fisheries", FAO, 1995); analysis of best international practices to apply the legal aspects, legal instruments (quotas, permissions, contractual arrangements) to ensure sustainable development of fisheries. 4. The analytical review of the fisheries sector of Kazakhstan as a source of income, employment growth, exports of products and other opportunities was prepared. The biological justification with the subject “Development of the biological justification to organize lake fish husbandry at the Dandi lake” was prepared. The training laboratory on commercial fisheries was opened at the Green Technology Center in Arnassay village, Akmola region with the presentation of the process of commercial fish rearing. 5. The registry of "green technology" is being developed. The round table was held among the UNDP projects engaged in the green economy to discuss and fill the registry. The terms of reference are being developed to prepare the registry in the form of the web-portal.

1. The recommendations for amending the legislation in the field of renewable sources of energy, including solar energy were presented to the Ministry of Energy of Kazakhstan. 2. The Atlas successfully operates on atlassolar.kz. The Atlas was greatly appreciated by international (NREL, IRENA) and national experts. The Atlas was presented at the EXPO 2017. 3. The identification of promising regions for solar energy development enabled to evaluate technically possible potential of using solar energy to produce heat and electric power and development prospects of solar energy. 4. The excluded and marginalized groups of people were engaged as part of the implementation of the first project output, i.e. implementation of demonstration projects: 1) The excluded groups of people: In the reporting period, a solar water heating system with the capacity of 17 250 l per day heated to 40 0С was installed in a specialized medical institution (neuropsychiatric residential hospital Kamkor) with 257 persons with permanent residence and 173 service personnel in Akkol village, Akmola region (135 km from capital Astana). The solar system will result in less diesel fuel used to supply hot water up to 50% in winter and from 80% to 90% in summer. 2) The excluded groups of people: Similar work was done in Yessik town, near the city of Almaty. A solar water heating system with the capacity of 22 600 l per day heated 60 0С was installed in a specialized medical institution (neuropsychiatric residential hospital Amanat) with 500 persons with permanent residence and 324 service personnel. This will result in less diesel fuel used to supply hot water up to 70% in winter and up to 100% in summer. Both hospitals used coal for heating and hot water before. 1) Improving the system of evaluating the performance of government bodies. 2) Improving the system of provision of public services through greater involvement of the public sector in the provision of public services and increase public awareness of the procedure for public services. 3) Harmonization of goals, functions and resources of government agencies. 4) Strengthening capacity of government officials in public administration.

1) Improved activity of state bodies based on recommendations made by the authorized state bodies on the assessment, by independent experts, the public and NGOs. A new component of the assessment system such as the independent expert assessment is piloted and tested. New information materials are created and distributed to support and promote the achievements of the assessment system. 2) Improved legislation in order for public services, the basic directions of further improving the quality of public services, conducted re-engineering business processes for public services, increased public awareness about the order of delivery of public services. More than 20 public services are re-engineered to improve the delivery of public services and to introduce necessary changes to legislation. Furthermore, the project has increased expertise and provided analytical support in the field of business process reengineering (BPR). The project supported the development of necessary handbook and publications on BPR. 3) Balanced system of public administration bodies functioning. Research support is organized for the conduction of functional review of selected state bodies. A relevant methodology is developed for transfer of state functions to competitive environment. A study on regional coefficients to improve harmonization of goals and functions has been done. 4) Capacity building exercises, conferences and seminars have been held to support awareness raising of public officials in public administration.

1) Improving the state bodies’ efficiency assessment system. 2) Improving the system of provision of public services through the conduction of business process reengineering (BPR) in the public sector and increase public awareness of the procedure for public services . 3) Harmonization of goals, functions and resources of government agencies. 4) Strengthening capacity of government officials in public administration.

1) The significant progress has been made in improvement the state bodies’ efficiency assessment system through transition to a new model of the assessment system and preparation of the expository information materials of the assessment system. The project team and experts provided necessary capacity and analytical support for the development of the model of the new assessment system. 2) The project has supported the business process reengineering of 23 public services. As a result, the concrete recommendations to change the standards and regulations to improve the provision of the public services have been prepared. The project supported the development of necessary handbook and publications on BPR. 3) The project team provided analytical and methodological support in redistributing functions between levels of public administration and conducted analysis of 20 functions for further redistribution. To increase harmonization of resources of government agencies, the project team prepared recommendations on bonus payment system of civil servants’. 4) The project team with government officials, the Evaluation Center of the Economic Research Institute and with attracted trainers organized a capacity building seminar on the results of assessment system.

comment.narrative: The Project Initiation Plan for the project document development

To held participatory consultations in focal landscapes to discuss the landscape planning approach&process with potential stakeholders to identify main threats for key landscapes and to discuss the potential activities for further grant activities at the landscape level. To start development of the project document as per GEF&UNDP requirements.

Eight consultation meetings arranged in all focal landscapes. The consultations ensured participation of a wide range of partners, and have totally covered 112 representatives of NGO's, youth organizations, business, sole proprietors and farmers, rural consumer cooperatives, entrepreneurs' associations, civil alliances, women associations, CAREC&UNDP etc. The consultations have ensured to formulate main challenges &risks focal ecosystems (steppe&desert) faces in each of the focal landscape, as well as to preliminary formulate the key outcomes and recommendations for each landscape. Those data consolidated and discussed with partners have formed the basis for formulation of the baseline in the project document, and the development of the main components and thematic priorities and directions of the SGP.
As part of project document development technical review was done with detailed stocktaking of the on-going and planned GEF, government, UNDP and other donor's prorammes&activities to correlate with GEF SGP activities within OP6. Also technical baseline assessment was done by IC&LC. The research data will become a part of baseline in the pre-document.
To develop project proposal and to submit to the GEF before April 2017

The draft of the prodoc developed is discussed with the GEF NSC, UNDP CO, partners, CSOs etc. Thank to a round of additional consultation meetings arranged in 6 focal landscapes, more construtive feedback on the project approach was obtained. Then the project was approved by LPAC& SGP NSC. Final prodoc & full package was submitted to GEF Sec in March. The project was approved by the GEF April 2017, and signed by UNOPS/UNDP and Government on 18/08/2017.

70,000 hectares is the area under resilient landscape management whose biodiversity, agro-ecosystems, and sustainable livelihoods are protected At least fifty organizations strengthened in technical, organizational and financial capacities (at least 30% led by women) avg direct beneficiaries per project 50, total 2,500 persons At least 8 energy efficient technologies piloted successfully in 7 pilot sites 795,6 tones of CO2 emissions are avoided At least 7 baseline landscape assessments done At least 7 functioning platforms (one per oblast), which include landscape policy considerations in their work-planning established At least 7 landscape strategies, one for targeted site is developed and implemented to achieve greater social and ecological resilience At least 50 community-based projects, implemented by CBOs and NGOs in partnership with others in the targeted landscapes, as outputs to achieve landscape level outcomes 40% of beneficiaries (disaggregated by gender) increased incomes as a result of sustainable and/or alternative practices At least five new technologies, practices or systems are replicated and up-scaled beyond the landscapes through the use of strategic projects 20-25 lessons learned documents developed; 7 case studies developed (1 per landscape) 100% of publications are gender-sensitive

comment.narrative:
Structural and functional degradation of desert and steppe ecosystems is occurring across Kazakhstan with the loss of important biodiversity and ecosystem services.
Wind and water erosion primarily due to unsustainable farming practices (crop and rice production) and extensive resource use (grazing, wood and grass harvesting) affect over 67 % of rain-fed areas of steppe and desert ecosystems, resulting in the loss of organic matter in topsoil (20% in the past 30 years) and reduction of crop yields by 20-30%.
The increasing annual harvest of riparian trees and reeds by local communities, local hunters, fishermen and farmers for use as fuel and for sale as well as for creating areas for fishing, grazing and harvesting has led to a dramatic reduction of the area and diversity of wooded zones.
Overgrazing is the leading cause of degradation of Kazakhstan’s rangelands, making this important agroecosystem susceptible to droughts, inadequate natural regeneration, widespread aerial transportation of sand and salt (affecting some 30 million ha) and formation of salinized or “solonchak” lands (more than 93 million ha). Pasturelands in Kazakhstan are affected by uneven use. Over 125 million ha of pastures lack watering points, thus restricting their utilization. On the other hand, some pastures are being over used - about 27.1 million ha of pastures that are located around settlements are classified as highly degraded due to unsustainable use.
Unsustainable hunting and fishing is on the rise.
Household and hazardous waste accumulation is increasing in rural and peri-urban areas.
Being a semiarid to arid country with a temperate climate, Kazakhstan faces significant desiccation in the face of climate change, and significant exacerbation of non-climate pressures.
The essential problem to be addressed by this project is that the necessary collective action in Kazakhstan for adaptive management of resources and ecosystem processes for sustainable development and global

1) Inception workshop arrangement with participation of main partners to discuss the project approach, Project Logframe, AWP for 2017-2018. 2) NSC approval of the Project, Logframe&AWP for 2017-2018. Preparation of the Inception report taking into account all the comments and changes. 3) Preparation for the baseline assessment in focal landscapes (7 oblasts)

1) The Inception workshop (both Internal & External session) was held on 30-31 October 2017 in Astana with participation of the main SGP partners from amongst CSOs, Local communities representatives, UNDP CO, UCP UNDP/GEF Global Manager, government officials, farmers, women association representatives, NSC members, experts on BD, CC, LD&gender experts. The Project Logframes& AWP were discussed, added and approved. 2) SGP NSC members approved the Project, AWP for 2017-2018 and Logframes on 23 November 2017. The inception report is prepared and shared with GEF UNDP UCP Manager and UNDP CO for comments. 3) Competition among NGOs for the baseline assessment to be arranged in focal landscapes in 2018 was held on 23 November. The NSC reviewed all the submitted applications, and approved the grant of $50,000 for Decenta PF. The MOA signed, the Baseline assessment workplan, budget, ToRs for experts approved.
